{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use Indian English|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox Court Case | name = ''Naz Foundation v. Govt. of NCT of Delhi'' | court = [[Delhi High Court]] | imagesize = | date decided = 2 July 2009 | full name = | judges = Chief Justice [[Ajit Prakash Shah]]
Justice S. Muralidhar | opinions = | citations = 160 Delhi Law Times 277 | keywords = [[Homosexuality]] |Overruled=''[[Suresh Kumar Koushal v. Naz Foundation]]'' by [[Supreme Court of India]]}} '''''Naz Foundation v. Govt. of NCT of Delhi'''''[http://lobis.nic.in/dhc/APS/judgement/02-07-2009/APS02072009CW74552001.pdf ''Naz Foundation v. Govt. of NCT of Delhi'', 160 Delhi Law Times 277 (Delhi High Court 2009)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090826035913/http://lobis.nic.in/dhc/APS/judgement/02-07-2009/APS02072009CW74552001.pdf |date=26 August 2009 }} is a landmark Indian case decided by a two-judge bench of the [[Delhi High Court]], which held that treating consensual [[homosexual]] sex between adults as a crime is a violation of [[Fundamental Rights in India|fundamental rights]] protected by [[India|India's]] [[Constitution of India|Constitution]]. The verdict resulted in the decriminalization of homosexual acts involving consenting adults throughout India. This was later overturned by the Supreme Court of India in [[Suresh Kumar Koushal vs. Naz Foundation]], in which a 2 judge bench reinstated [[Section 377 of the Indian Penal Code]]. However, even that was overturned by a 5 judge bench in [[Navtej Singh Johar v. Union of India]] in 2018, decriminalizing homosexuality once again. {{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/sep/06/indian-supreme-court-decriminalises-homosexuality|title=Campaigners celebrate as India decriminalises homosexuality|last=Safi|first=Michael|date=2018-09-06|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-09-07}} ==Facts== [[Section 377 of the Indian Penal Code|Section 377]] of the [[Indian Penal Code]], introduced during [[British rule of India]], criminalizes "carnal intercourse against the order of nature". This phrase was interpreted to mean all forms of sexual activity other than heterosexual penile-vaginal intercourse.''Naz Foundation v. Govt. of NCT of Delhi'', [http://www.ilga.org/news-upload/Delhi_high_court_decision.pdf 160 Delhi Law Times 277, p. 2] (Delhi High Court 2009) The movement to repeal Section 377 was led by the [[Naz Foundation (India) Trust]], a non-governmental organization, which filed a [[public interest litigation|lawsuit]] in the [[Delhi High Court]] in 2001, seeking legalisation of homosexual intercourse between consenting adults.{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/chronology-8yearlong-legal-battle-for-gay-rights/96152-3.html|title=Chronology: 8-year-long legal battle for gay rights|publisher=CNN-IBN|accessdate=2009-07-02}} This was the second such petition, the first filed in 1994 by [[AIDS Bhedbhav Virodhi Andolan]].{{cite book|editor1-last=Fernandez|editor1-first=Bina|title=Humjinsi: A Resource Book on Lesbian, Gay and Bisexual Rights in India|date=1999|publisher=India Centre for Human Rights and Law|location=Mumbai|page=35}} In 2003, the Delhi High Court refused to consider a petition regarding the legality of the law, saying that the petitioners had no ''[[locus standi]]'' in the matter. Naz Foundation appealed to the [[Supreme Court of India]] against the decision of the High Court to dismiss the petition on technical grounds. The Supreme Court decided that Naz Foundation had the standing to file a public interest lawsuit in this case, and sent the case back to the Delhi High Court to reconsider it on the merits.{{cite web|url=http://us.rediff.com/news/2006/feb/03gay.htm?q=tp&file=.htm|title=Gay Rights is matter of Public Interest: SC|publisher=Rediff News|date=2006-02-03|author=Sheela Bhatt|accessdate=2009-07-07}} In 2006, the [[National AIDS Control Organisation]] filed an affidavit stating that the enforcement of Section 377 violates [[LGBT]] rights.{{cite news|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2006-07-20/delhi/27802911_1_naco-affidavit-naz-foundation|title=Govt's AIDS cell pushes to legalise homosexuality|publisher=The Times of India|date=2006-07-20|accessdate=2009-11-27}} Subsequently, there was a significant intervention in the case by a Delhi-based coalition of LGBT, women's and human rights activists called "Voices Against 377", which supported the demand to "read down" section 377 to exclude adult consensual sex from within its purview.{{cite news|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2008-05-20/india/27743991_1_decriminalise-homosexuality-gay-couple-pil-on-gay-rights|title=Delhi HC to take up PIL on LGBT rights|publisher=The Times of India|date=2008-05-20|author=Shibu Thomas|accessdate=2009-07-07}} ==Judgement== The case came up for hearing before a bench comprising Chief Justice [[Ajit Prakash Shah]] and Justice S. Muralidhar, and the judgment was delivered on 2 July 2009.{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/delhi-high-court-legalises-consensual-gay-sex/96148-3.html|title=Delhi High Court legalises consensual gay sex|publisher=[[CNN-IBN]]|accessdate=2009-07-02}} The Court located the rights to dignity and privacy within the right to life and liberty guaranteed by Article 21 (under the [[Fundamental_Rights_in_India#Right_to_equality|fundamental Right to Freedom]] charter) of the Constitution, and held that criminalization of consensual gay sex violated these rights.''Naz Foundation v. Govt. of NCT of Delhi'', [http://www.ilga.org/news-upload/Delhi_high_court_decision.pdf 160 Delhi Law Times 277, p. 48] (Delhi High Court 2009) The Court also held that Section 377 offends the guarantee of equality enshrined in Article 14 (under the [[Fundamental_Rights_in_India#Right_to_equality|fundamental Right to Equality]] charter) of the Constitution, because it creates an unreasonable classification and targets homosexuals as a class.''Naz Foundation v. Govt. of NCT of Delhi'', [http://www.ilga.org/news-upload/Delhi_high_court_decision.pdf 160 Delhi Law Times 277, p. 91] (Delhi High Court 2009) Public ''animus'' and disgust towards a particular social group or vulnerable minority, it held, is not a valid ground for classification under Article 14. Article 15 of the Constitution forbids discrimination based on certain characteristics, including sex. The Court held that the word "sex" includes not only biological sex but also sexual orientation, and therefore discrimination on the ground of sexual orientation is not permissible under Article 15.''Naz Foundation v. Govt. of NCT of Delhi'', [http://www.ilga.org/news-upload/Delhi_high_court_decision.pdf 160 Delhi Law Times 277, p. 104] (Delhi High Court 2009) The Court also noted that the right to life under Article 21 includes the right to health, and concluded that Section 377 is an impediment to public health because it hinders [[HIV]]-prevention efforts.''Naz Foundation v. Govt. of NCT of Delhi'', [http://www.ilga.org/news-upload/Delhi_high_court_decision.pdf 160 Delhi Law Times 277, p. 72] (Delhi High Court 2009) The Court did not strike down Section 377 as a whole. The section was declared unconstitutional insofar it criminalises consensual sexual acts of adults in private. The judgement keeps intact the provision insofar as it applies to non-consensual non-vaginal intercourse and intercourse with minors. The court stated that the judgement would hold until [[Parliament of India|Parliament]] chose to amend the law.''Naz Foundation v. Govt. of NCT of Delhi'', [http://www.ilga.org/news-upload/Delhi_high_court_decision.pdf 160 Delhi Law Times 277, p. 132] (Delhi High Court 2009) ==Significance== According to an eyewitness account, as the Chief Justice read out the conclusion, "an audible gasp went around the room. By the time the Chief Justice had finished reading the conclusion of the judgment, people were openly weeping and there were handshakes and hugs all around."{{cite news|url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/node/43776/print|title=Reforming Macaulay|last=Bhardwaj|first=Kajal|date=2009-05-07|work=Deccan Chronicle|accessdate=2009-11-27}} Within hours, news of the judgment was being carried by international news sites. Lawrence Liang called it India's ''[[Roe v. Wade|Roe]]'' moment.{{cite web|url=http://lawandotherthings.blogspot.com/2009/07/navigating-noteworthy-and-nebulous-in.html|title=Navigating the Noteworthy and Nebulous in Naz Foundation|author=Raghavan, Vikram|accessdate=2009-11-27}} Activists,{{cite news|url=http://www.hindu.com/2009/07/04/stories/2009070451260300.htm|title=Gay sex judgment greeted with delight and jubilation|date=2009-07-04|work=''[[The Hindu]]''|accessdate=2009-11-27|location=Chennai, India}} commentators and organizations like [[Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS|UNAIDS]]{{cite news|url=http://www.hindu.com/2009/07/03/stories/2009070361381800.htm|title=Judgment on Section 377 welcomed|last=Aarti|first=Dhar|work=''The Hindu''|accessdate=2009-11-27|location=Chennai, India|date=2009-07-03}} lauded the decision, while some religious leaders{{cite news|url=http://www.hindu.com/2009/07/03/stories/2009070361341800.htm|title=Muslim clerics feel family system will be destroyed|last=Khan|first=Atiq|date=2009-07-03|work=The Hindu|accessdate=2009-11-27|location=Chennai, India}} and politicians{{cite news|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/bangalore/interview_decriminalising-homosexuality-will-send-wrong-signals_1272161|title=Decriminalising homosexuality will send wrong signals|last=Hunasavadi|first=Srikanth|date=2009-08-07|work=[[DNA (newspaper)|DNA]]|accessdate=2009-11-27}} voiced displeasure over the judgment. Some special leave petitions were filed in the Supreme Court requesting an interim stay of the judgment, pending an appeal. However, the Supreme Court rejected those requests.{{cite news|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/sc-declines-to-stay-hc-verdict-on-homosexuality/491686/0|title=SC declines to stay HC verdict on homosexuality|date=2009-07-20|work=[[The Indian Express]]|accessdate=2009-11-27}} A batch of appeals were filed with the [[Supreme Court of India|Supreme Court]], challenging the Delhi High Court judgment. On 27 March 2012, the Supreme Court reserved verdict on these.{{cite news|title=Verdict reserved on appeals in gay sex case|work=''The Hindu''|date=27 March 2012|accessdate=3 October 2012|location=New Delhi, India|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article3250607.ece}} After initially opposing the judgment, the [[Attorney General of India|Attorney General]] [[G. E. Vahanvati]] decided not to file any appeal against the Delhi High Court's verdict, stating, "insofar as [Section 377 of the Indian Penal Code] criminalises consensual sexual acts of adults in private [before it was struck down by the High Court] was imposed upon Indian society due to the moral views of the [[British Raj|British rulers]]." On December 11, 2013, the Supreme Court's two member bench (Justices [[G. S. Singhvi]] and S. J. Mukhopadhaya) overturned the decision of the Delhi High Court. It said that the 2009 order of the High Court is "constitutionally unsustainable as only Parliament can change a law, not courts".{{cite news|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/supreme-court-says-gay-sex-is-a-criminal-offence-activists-to-seek-review-457216|title=Supreme Court says gay sex is a criminal offence, activists to seek review|date=2013-12-11}} But, on 6 September 2018, a five judge constitutional bench of the Supreme Court of India, in a landmark judgement, decriminalized homosexuality and banned discrimination based on sexual orientation.{{Cite news|url=https://amp.theguardian.com/world/2018/sep/06/indian-supreme-court-decriminalises-homosexuality#referrer=https://www.google.com&_tf=From%20%251$s|title=Campaigners celebrate as India decriminalises homosexuality|last=Safi|first=Michael|date=2018-09-06|work=the Guardian|access-date=2018-09-07}} ==Notes== {{Reflist|2}} == External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090826035913/http://lobis.nic.in/dhc/APS/judgement/02-07-2009/APS02072009CW74552001.pdf Naz Foundation v. Govt. of NCT of Delhi] * [http://www.altlawforum.org/news/gender-and-sexuality/the-377-campaign/The%20right%20that%20Dares%20to%20Speak%20its%20Name.pdf The Right that Dares to Speak Its Name], Alternative Law Forum * [http://lawandotherthings.blogspot.com/search/label/Naz%20Foundation Law and Other Things on Naz Foundation] * [https://archive.is/20120630065247/http://www.nazindia.org/advocacy.htm Naz Foundation India Trust] {{DEFAULTSORT:Naz Foundation V. Govt. Of Nct Of Delhi}} [[Category:LGBT rights in India]] [[Category:Indian case law]] [[Category:2009 in case law]] [[Category:2009 in LGBT history]] [[Category:2009 in India]] [[Category:LGBT rights case law]] [[Category:Delhi High Court]] [[Category:High Courts of India cases]]

{{Infobox company | name = NewsRight, LLC | logo = | caption = | type = | foundation = January 2012 | location = [[New York City]] | key_people = [[David Westin]], CEO | industry = | products = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | owner = [[Associated Press]]
([[#Founding members|& 28 others]]) | num_employees = 10+ | parent = }} '''NewsRight, LLC''' (formerly News Licensing Group, NLG) is an online [[Content (media)|content]]-tracking and [[copyright|licensing]] company. The company tracks original content using encoded hidden data which sends back to the registry information on where the content is being used. This information is used by NewsRight to convert unauthorized websites, blogs and newsgathering services into paying customers.{{cite news |title=AP, NYTimes, McClatchy, others launch NewsRight online rights clearinghouse |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/ap-nytimes-mcclatchy-others-launch-newsright-online-rights-clearinghouse/2012/01/05/gIQAgBwxcP_story.html |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=2012-01-05 |agency=[[Associated Press]] |accessdate=2012-01-09}} The company does not own the copyrights to the content; its role is limited to brokering business relationships and contracts.{{cite news |title=NewsRight Launches With 29 Publishers; ‘Not A Litigation Shop’ |url=http://paidcontent.org/article/419-newsright-launches-with-29-publishers-not-a-litigation-shop/ |publisher=[[paidContent]] |date=2012-01-05 |first=Staci D. |last=Kramer |accessdate=2012-01-09}} NewsRight was launched on January 5, 2012 as a partnership between the [[Associated Press]] and 28 other news organizations. [[David Westin]], former head of [[ABC News]], was named its first [[CEO]]. The AP began their own tracking technology in October 2010—known as News Registry—to help publishers track and license their content online. News Registry was spun off as the News Licensing Group (NLG) in July 2011 before being launched in its current form in January 2012.{{cite press release |title=AP board approves independent agency to license digital news |url=http://www.ap.org/pages/about/pressreleases/pr_020311a.html |publisher=[[Associated Press]] |date=2011-02-03 |accessdate=2012-01-09 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/64ZiT4WwG |archivedate=2012-01-09}} As of January 2012, negotiations are ongoing to bring aboard [[Gannett Company]], [[Tribune Company]], [[Cox Enterprises]] and [[News Corporation]] as participants.{{cite web |title=AP, 28 news orgs launch NewsRight to collect licensing fees from aggregators |url=http://www.poynter.org/latest-news/business-news/the-biz-blog/157817/ap-28-news-orgs-launch-newsright-to-collect-licensing-fees-from-aggregators/ |publisher=[[Poynter Institute]] |date=2012-01-05 |first=Rick |last=Edmonds |accessdate=2012-01-09}} The company's launch is said by analysts to be motivated by news-filtering services such as [[Meltwater Group|Meltwater]] and news aggregators such as ''[[The Huffington Post]]''.{{cite news |title=Is the AP's NewsRight a Carrot or a Stick? |url=http://www.businessweek.com/technology/is-the-aps-newsright-a-carrot-or-a-stick-01062012.html |magazine=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]] |date=2012-01-06 |first=Mathew |last=Ingram |accessdate=2012-01-09}} The AP has spent years fighting the free sharing of content online which has disrupted its traditional role as a [[newswire]]. ==Founding members== {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| *[[Advance Publications]] *[[Associated Press]] *[[Axel Springer AG]] *[[A.
